Answer: Forever. The spacecraft have been on backup maneuvering thrusters for over a decade. If they turned around and burned all remaining propellant, it wouldn’t slow them down by more than a percent or so. They used a big rocket to get going that fast, and multiple planetary slingshots to boost back up to speed as the sun’s gravity slowed them down. They aren’t coming back unless some Vogon destructor fleet picks them up on its way here.
name: C Stuart Hardwick

Answer: Behind you, a bright star.In front of you, mostly nothingness, and a lonely, uneventful journey.It is too late to go back.You can’t remember the last time you saw a friendly face or heard a cheerful voice.Nothing to see for thousands of years. Your next encounter with a star will be in 40,000 years.I hope you brought a good book.Scream all you like, no one can hear you.Behind you, a bright star.In front of you, mostly nothingness, and a lonely, uneventful journey.It is too late to go back.You can’t remember the last time you saw a friendly face or heard a cheerful voice.Nothing to see for thousands of years. name: Marco DiGirolamo
question: https://www.quora.com/Is-it-possible-that-in-the-future-we-can-have-a-spacecraft-that-goes-faster-and-overtake-Voyager-1-Same-goes-with-advancing-technology-in-far-future

Answer: Of course. Voyager used a particularly good positioning of orbits of the larger planets, but it’s purpose was to pass those at a speed at which good observations could be done, especially considering the limitations of instruments at that time.It would have been quite possible to achieve a faster speed but would have been counter-productive. We could launch a craft now that would pass it, but why would we go to that bother? The data to be gained would be limited, and even ten times faster it wouldn’t get to anything interesting, like another star system, until long after it had ceased to functOf course. Voyager used a particularly good positioning of orbits of the larger planets, but it’s purpose was to pass those at a speed at which good observations could be done, especially considering the limitations of instruments at that time.It would have been quite possible to achieve a faster speed but would have been counter-productive. We could launch a craft now that would pass it, but why would we go to that bother? The data to be gained would be limited, and even ten times faster it wouldn’t get to anything interesting, like another star system, until long after it had ceased to function.
name: Dave Consiglio
question: https://www.quora.com/Is-it-possible-that-in-the-future-we-can-have-a-spacecraft-that-goes-faster-and-overtake-Voyager-1-Same-goes-with-advancing-technology-in-far-future

Answer: We don’t have the one updated technology that would make it worth it.Sure, the Voyagers are antiques. Their cameras are toys compared to what we have today. We have made huge strides in detector sensitivity, not to mention communication rates. We could build a probe vastly superior to the Voyagers in every way but one, and we could build that probe for a fraction of the cost.But we’d still be limiWe don’t have the one updated technology that would make it worth it.Sure, the Voyagers are antiques. Their cameras are toys compared to what we have today. We have made huge strides in detector sensitivity, not to mention communication rates. We could build a probe vastly superior to the Voyagers in every way but one, and we could build that probe for a fraction of the cost.But we’d still be limited by the rocket.You see, Voyagers 1 and 2 were launched on the Titan IIIE rocket.To this day, we really can’t do much better than that rocket. Sure, we have made minor improvements in rocket design. But essentially we’re just making them reusable and cheaper, not faster.It simply doesn’t get much better than kerosene and liquid oxygen…for chemical rockets.Now, if we built a nuclear rocket, or a space elevator,...
name: Leon Brennan
question: https://www.quora.com/Is-it-possible-that-in-the-future-we-can-have-a-spacecraft-that-goes-faster-and-overtake-Voyager-1-Same-goes-with-advancing-technology-in-far-future

Answer: The speeds of Voyager 1 were not constant the whole time it has been travelling away from the earth. It was launched with so much speed by powerful rockets and has had to fight the pull of first earth and then the sun slowing it down. It was able to use some clever slingshot maneuvers to increase its speed around Jupiter,Saturn, Uranus and Neptune as a gravity assist as it blew by those planets in a rare and convenient alignment.Still with a speed well above solar escape velocity it is clearly leaving the solar system at a brisk pace for most human projects.We are not at the limit of our speedThe speeds of Voyager 1 were not constant the whole time it has been travelling away from the earth. It was launched with so much speed by powerful rockets and has had to fight the pull of first earth and then the sun slowing it down. It was able to use some clever slingshot maneuvers to increase its speed around Jupiter,Saturn, Uranus and Neptune as a gravity assist as it blew by those planets in a rare and convenient alignment.Still with a speed well above solar escape velocity it is clearly leaving the solar system at a brisk pace for most human projects.We are not at the limit of our speed capability… however it would take considerably larger and more costly rockets and some luck with planetary alignment for any slingshots….But with a 42 year headstart (1977 to 2019), we’d have to go twice as fast on the average to even catch Voyager in 84 years… I would say its not likely to happen. Voyager has satisfied many of the questions about very deep solar system conditions; there’s not much out there to really see, and its really way too slow to get to another solar system in any reasonable time even if we were to go 10 times as fast.
name: Robert Frost
question: https://www.quora.com/Is-it-possible-that-in-the-future-we-can-have-a-spacecraft-that-goes-faster-and-overtake-Voyager-1-Same-goes-with-advancing-technology-in-far-future

Answer: This February my wife was diagnosed and given six months to live. When I heard the doctor tell her “six months”, it felt likeI met my wife, Jess, twenty-one years ago when she was nineteen.Our parents owned side-by-side cabins in the northern part of New York and we both happened to be along for the week-long hunting trip our fathers planned that year.Jess' father was a skilled hunter and could hit a headshot from a mile away — same as my dad.Jess and I didn't hunt with them — we hung out by the lake.The moment I saw Jess I fell in lThis February my wife was diagnosed and given six months to live. When I heard the doctor tell her “six months”, it felt likeI met my wife, Jess, twenty-one years ago when she was nineteen.Our parents owned side-by-side cabins in the northern part of New York and we both happened to be along for the week-long hunting trip our fathers planned that year.Jess' father was a skilled hunter and could hit a headshot from a mile away — same as my dad.Jess and I didn't hunt with them — we hung out by the lake.The moment I saw Jess I fell in love. We've been together ever since.But now, now that she has an expiration date, I just don't know what to do — I'm scared and lost.Monday morning at work I was telling my best friend and supervisor, Timmy, about my wife's condition. Timmy told me that I.T. or Intelligent Terrestrial just came out with their latest models.These models are different than those of yesteryear because they are 52% mechanical and 48% biological.Timmy said all you have to do is mail a sample of DNA to I.T. and upload a digital copy of your consciousness through an app. You can then purchase a custom made clone at an age of your choice. When the clone arrives it will turn on, study it's surroundings and await a consciousness download.“Oh my God Timmy, what's the catch?”“The price, Leon.”When I got home from work, Jess and I plugged in and uploaded a digital copy of our entire conscious catalog to I.T. and then mailed off DNA samples.Jess asked me what age I wanted her to be. It felt awkward to say “twenty”, but I did it — I was honest. I miss her smooth, youthful skin and I want her to be young and healthy — especially if I have to cash my entire 401K in to afford it.We told her parents that we were going to basically bring her back from the dead and her father threatened to shoot any abomination that we brought into this world.One month later, on a day that Jess was particularly ill, the doorbell rang.Jess and I dragged the box through the door and laid it on the living room floor. I gently cut along the lines and when I opened the flaps, there,she,was.The last time my heart fluttered like this was the day I met her.Jess helped me lift I.T. out of the box and sit I.T. up.I.T. was warm and soft. I.T. was mine. I paid for I.T. I own I.T.Machines like this don't have rights — even though they are part biological, the governments recognize them in the same way they would a lawnmower — so, as I said, I.T. is my possession.The science behind uploading a digital consciousness is so cutting edge, that the laws just haven't caught up yet.Jess turned I.T. on and I.T. looked right into my eyes. I was in love — with two women, but, it was the same woman. We hadn't uploaded Jess' consciousness yet, so, I.T. was running on basic programming, but I.T. was gorgeous.Jess asked me what I wanted to do, and for the first time in a very long time — I lied to her.I told her we should go shopping and buy I.T. some clothes.I.T. doesn't seem to have a personality yet.“Hello…. Smile…”Jess picked outfits for both of them and we went for a walk through the park together. It was amazing — I was so happy.We walked down a cozy little trail and found a tuck away to sit and talk.I.T. watched and studied every move Jess and I made. I.T. was learning and adapting.I.T. was becoming aware.At one point Jess and I got distracted and I.T. wandered off. When we found I.T., I.T. was gazing at the sky.I asked I.T. what it was doing. I.T. said, “Where do I come from?”“You come from Heaven. You are my angel.”That answer seemed to work for I.T. We all walked back to the car and headed home.When we got home, Jess immediately started coughing. She fell to the ground and I tried to help her, but I didn't know what to do.Jess passed away right then. It was finally over.I called her family and the police. It took an hour for them to remove the body. I had Jess 2.0 sitting in my back room waiting for them to leave.After the police left, I plugged I.T. into my laptop and downloaded Jess' consciousness.After the download was complete, we walked outside and I looked into her gigantic brown eyes. I asked her, “Is it you, Jess?”She smiled and said, “It is, silly — now kiss me.”Her head slammed back. I didn't know if she was glitching or what and then I heard a bang and saw a hole above her left eye.My beautiful Jessica died twice today. I was crushed.Over the next two decades, I fell into a deep, dark, alcohol-fueled depression. Although I had developed a serious alcohol problem, I was able to work and save every single penny I earned.After twenty years of saving, I decided I wanted both of them back — the twenty-year-old Jess and the forty-year-old Jess.I sent my entire life savings off to I.T. and in one month, my doorbell rang.I cut the box open and wept when I saw my angel(s).I turned them on.I also clothed them. The younger version of me may have left them in the nude, but at this age, I just want my companion(s) back.The ladies helped me back to my room to lay down. I was so tired from all the excitement.I've waited and worked an entire lifetime to be with the woman I love. And now, at long last — she is beside me.I died, on that very night as a happy man.One day later, the doorbell rang. It seems my beautiful Jessicas used my direct deposit life insurance benefit to make a purchase.They gently cut the box open.And turned me on.You ask where technology will be in 2050?We will be everywhere.LeonSpecial thanks:Cameron — Dear friend. Thank you so much for all your help with bringing this idea to life. You are awesome. I'm proud to call you friend.Kinsalynn — My sister and friend. Your help with makeup and photography was an absolute godsend — thank you so much. I love and appreciate you. P.S. you took over 300 pictures in an eight hour span. Thank you from the bottom of my heart:)Brooke — Even with a bullet hole in the head, you are deliciously gorgeous. You spent eight hours modeling for my Quora answer today and never once did you fail to impress or inspire me. I am honored to be friends with you.Jess —

name: Robert Frost
question: https://www.quora.com/Is-it-possible-that-in-the-future-we-can-have-a-spacecraft-that-goes-faster-and-overtake-Voyager-1-Same-goes-with-advancing-technology-in-far-future

Answer: The main difference is that we’d be able to fit better sensors in a lower weight, and possibly lower power requirements. Considering that Voyager was initially planned to only last 3 years, maybe we would have increased the number of sensors until the whole package was as heavy as it is now, or maybe we would have used the lower power load to make it with a smaller load of plutonium and had a lighter and faster spacecraft. But it’s hard to argue with the success of a spacecraft that was designed for 3 years that has lasted as long as it has.
name: Viktor T. Toth
question: https://www.quora.com/Is-it-possible-that-in-the-future-we-can-have-a-spacecraft-that-goes-faster-and-overtake-Voyager-1-Same-goes-with-advancing-technology-in-far-future

Answer: No.  The Voyager missions were designed to take advantage of a planetary alignment that allowed a "Grand Tour".  It is a six year window that happens about once every 175 years.  The next one begins in 2153.  We don't plan missions that far in advance.Continue ReadingNo.  The Voyager missions were designed to take advantage of a planetary alignment that allowed a "Grand Tour". Many businesses around the world are being effectively run by founders who live far away from their employees and only get to communicate virtually.Founders have access to large pools of professionals to choose from using freelance platforms like Upwork, Guru etc.Looking at all these from a financial perspective, foundersYES. Many businesses around the world are being effectively run by founders who live far away from their employees and only get to communicate virtually.Founders have access to large pools of professionals to choose from using freelance platforms like Upwork, Guru etc.Looking at all these from a financial perspective, founders can save more by not having to invest in office buildings or buying office equipments. Answer: MCU Wakanda has one of the least-effective militaries I’ve ever seen. I think a single US army division could’ve flattened them within a day.Now, to be fair, most of these errors are strategic (long-term planning) as opposed to tactical (immediate execution), but I’ll go through the full list:Strategic:MCU Wakanda has one of the least-effective militaries I’ve ever seen. I think a single US army division could’ve flattened them within a day.Now, to be fair, most of these errors are strategic (long-term planning) as opposed to tactical (immediate execution), but I’ll go through the full list:Strategic:Seriously, just look at them! No helmets, no body armor. The only person here carrying an actual anti-personnel weapon ins Bucky. No mortars or machine-guns, no fortifications, no barbed wire or trenches, no tank support, no air support.I could go on, and on, and on…But what’s the point? It’s obvious that Wakanda’s military readiness is on par with a drunk who realizes he’s driven to the bar and has no way home. So, let’s talk about what Wakanda should have done given even the events of the film (a day or so).Tactical:Like, I don’t know if those monsters can swim or not, but I’m sure as hell that they don’t swim as fast as they can run.Once again, I could go on. But it’s a movie. If you liked it, great! Just ignore the fact that, as I walked out of the theater, I literally heard an eight-year-old saying“But that doesn’t make sense. Why did they have spears and not guns?”
